com.xhive.core.interfaces
Interface XhiveDriverIf

public interface XhiveDriverIf

The X-Hive/DB driver provides factory methods for different functionalities of X-Hive/DB. You can access the driver through the XhiveDriverFactory.

(c) X-Hive Corporation B.V. (www.x-hive.com)

Since:
X-Hive/DB 1.0

Nested Class Summary
static interface XhiveDriverIf.XhiveDriverObserverIf
          An interface that can be implemented by application code to be notified of events in the X-Hive/DB subsystem.

Method Detail

init

void init(XhivePageCacheIf pageCache)
Initialize the X-Hive/DB subsystem using a page cache that was created with XhiveFederationFactoryIf.createPageCache(int). All server threads are started as daemon threads.

You should only initialize a driver once in your application, use isInitialized() to check if you get a driver in multiple places in your application.

Parameters:
pageCache - The page cache to use.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

init

void init(XhivePageCacheIf pageCache,
          javax.net.SocketFactory socketFactory)
Initialize the X-Hive/DB subsystem using a page cache that was created with XhiveFederationFactoryIf.createPageCache(int). If this is a remote client, use the specified SocketFactory to create sockets to connect to the server. You can use this, for example, to create SSL sockets that use your own trust manager. All server threads are started as daemon threads.

Parameters:
pageCache - The page cache to use.
socketFactory - A factory to create client sockets.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

init

void init(int cachePages)
Initialize the X-Hive/DB subsystem using the specified number of cache pages. All server threads are started as daemon threads.

You should only initialize a driver once in your application, use isInitialized() to check if you get a driver in multiple places in your application.

Parameters:
cachePages - The number of pages in the database cache.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

init

void init(int cachePages,
          javax.net.SocketFactory socketFactory)
Initialize the X-Hive/DB subsystem using the specified number of cache pages. If this is a remote client, use the specified SocketFactory to create sockets to connect to the server. You can use this, for example, to create SSL sockets that use your own trust manager. All server threads are started as daemon threads.

Parameters:
cachePages - The number of pages in the database cache.
socketFactory - A factory to create client sockets.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

isInitialized

boolean isInitialized()
Check whether the X-Hive/DB subsystem has been initialized for this driver.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

startListenerThread

void startListenerThread(java.net.ServerSocket serverSocket)
Starts a thread that listens on the specified server socket to accept connections from remote clients. When the driver is closed, the socket will also be closed. If you close the socket yourself first, the listening thread will exit. This method can be called multiple times to listen to multiple server sockets.

Parameters:
serverSocket - The server socket to listen for client connections.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

acceptConnection

void acceptConnection(java.net.Socket socket)
Use the provided socket as a connection to this X-Hive/DB federation. This can be useful if for some reason you need to run your own listener thread. The socket will be closed when the X-Hive/DB server stops, e.g. when close() is called on this driver.

Parameters:
socket - The socket to use for a remote connection.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

createSession

XhiveSessionIf createSession()
Creates a new session object.

Returns:
The new session object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

createSession

XhiveSessionIf createSession(java.lang.String name)
Creates a new session object with a specified name. This name can be useful to identify a session for debugging purposes. It is only used in printSessionInformation(java.io.PrintWriter).

Parameters:
name - The name of the session.
Returns:
The new session object.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

close

void close()
Close the driver, stopping any internal threads and freeing all occupied resources. Also closes any server sockets that were used in startListenerThread(java.net.ServerSocket). This method can only be called if there are no open transactions in sessions of this driver. When this method has succeeded, the driver is no longer considered initialized. If desired, you can then call one of the init(com.xhive.core.interfaces.XhivePageCacheIf) methods again.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

Returns:

Throws:
XhiveException - If no transaction is active for the current thread.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 1.0

getStringProperty

java.lang.String getStringProperty(java.lang.String propertyName)
Gets the value of a string property. The values of properties may be defined in xhive.properties. All properties have a default value. These default values are overwritten by the values defined in xhive.properties.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

setStringProperty

void setStringProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
                       java.lang.String value)
Sets the value of a string property. This overrides both the defaults as well as values that may have been read from xhive.properties. Set properties remain valid as long as the application is running.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 3.0

setUserClassLoader

void setUserClassLoader(java.lang.ClassLoader classLoader)
Sets the class-loader to use to find user defined classes. These are used in:
  • Context Conditioned Index nodefilters.
  • User defined functions in XPath.
  • User defined functions in XQuery.
  • Full text index analyzer classes.
Most common usage of this method is in a J2EE servlet environment, where the user classes are in the servlet directory, and the xhive-jars are in a servlet engine directory, loaded by a different class-loader. Then you may want to call 
XhiveDriverFactory.getDriver().setUserClassLoader(this.getClass().getClassLoader());

You should only call this method once. All applications that share the same XhiveDriverFactory class (where that class was loaded by some classloader will share the same classloader for loading such user defined classes).

The classloader set here can be overruled by setting a classloader on a specific session. Use this method if you know all sessions will operate in the same classloading context, use the one on XhiveSessionIf if you need more finegrained control (e.g. if you have, or may have, multiple servlet contexts using X-Hive/DB).

Since:
X-Hive/DB 3.0.1
See Also:
XhiveSessionIf.setUserClassLoader(ClassLoader), XhiveCCIndexIf.indexDocument(Document), XhiveXQueryExtensionFunctionIf, XhiveXPathContextIf.addFunctionBinding(String, String)

Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.1

printSessionInformation

void printSessionInformation(java.io.PrintWriter printWriter)
Prints debug information on current sessions and locks to the specified PrintWriter. The format of this information is not specified and can change between X-Hive/DB releases. In order not to disturb transaction handling, no locks are taken on internal data structures while printing this information. This means that the information shown could be inconsistent and also that this method could throw unexpected exceptions.

Parameters:
printWriter - The writer to send the debug information to.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

getDatabaseNames

Returns:
An Iterator of String objects containing the names of the databases in the federation.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

XhiveSecurityConfigIf getSecurityConfig()
Retrieves an interface to manipulate the security configuration of the X-Hive/DB server.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

getMaxOpenDataFiles

int getMaxOpenDataFiles()
Retrieves the maximum number of database files opened at a time. This limits the number of file descriptors, handles or whatever your operating system calls them that are used for data files. A higher value not only allows more files to be open simultaneously (saving time consuming open/close calls), but also allows each single file to be opened multiple times, which allows more threads to read from or write to a file concurrently. This may help performance, particularly if single database files are spread over multiple physical disks, for instance when using RAID 0 or RAID 5.

Returns:
The maximum number of open data files.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0
See Also:
setMaxOpenDataFiles(int)

setMaxOpenDataFiles

void setMaxOpenDataFiles(int numFiles)
Sets the maximum number of database files opened at a time. The default value is 256.

Parameters:
numFiles - The maximum number of open data files.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0
See Also:
getMaxOpenDataFiles()

getPathMapper

XhiveFederationFactoryIf.PathMapper getPathMapper()
Retrieves the currently set path mapper.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0
See Also:
setPathMapper(com.xhive.core.interfaces.XhiveFederationFactoryIf.PathMapper)

setPathMapper

void setPathMapper(XhiveFederationFactoryIf.PathMapper mapper)
Sets a path mapper. This path mapper maps directories for newly created files that are stored in the federation log. During recovery or when replicating, the federation log is used to redo modifications to the federation. If those modifications involve creating new files, you may want to store those files in another directory than the original one.

Parameters:
mapper - An implementation of XhiveFederationFactoryIf.PathMapper.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0

configureReplicator

void configureReplicator(java.lang.String master,
                         java.lang.String replicatorId)
Configure the X-Hive/DB subsystem to do replication of an X-Hive/DB server. This driver must have been created using the bootstrap filename of the replica. This method must be called before init(com.xhive.core.interfaces.XhivePageCacheIf) or after close(). After this method is called, either init(int) or init(int, SocketFactory) must be called for replication to start.

You can unconfigure replication and run this replica as a regular federation by calling this method with all null parameters.

Parameters:
master - The URL of the X-Hive/DB server to replicate. This must be of the form xhive://hostname:port or xhives://hostname:port.
replicatorId - The id of this replicator. It must have been registered with the server using XhiveFederationIf.registerReplicator(java.lang.String).
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0

getStatistics

java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Number> getStatistics()
Retrieve performance statistics of the X-Hive/DB server.

The statistics are live: the values returned by this map can change with each call to its get method. The actual statistics counter can be reset by putting a value into this map. You cannot change the keys in this map, adding a key has no effect, removing a key resets its counter to 0, calling its clear() method will reset all counters to 0.

The reported statistics are subject to change without notice in future versions of X-Hive/DB. Please do not rely on the existence of specific statistics in your application.

Returns:
A java.util.Map where the key is a java.util.String with the name of the statistic and the value is a java.util.Long with its value.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

addObserver

void addObserver(XhiveDriverIf.XhiveDriverObserverIf observer)
Add an observer that will be notified of events in the X-Hive/DB server.

If a serious error occurs in the X-Hive/DB subsystem, it will halt to avoid corrupting data. Application code can be notified of this by registering an observer with the driver. The XhiveDriverIf.XhiveDriverObserverIf.notify(int, XhiveDriverIf, Object) method of the observer will be called with the java.lang.Throwable that caused the fatal error as the argument. This is only useful on an internal server that runs directly on the federation files. Remote notification is not supported.

The driver keeps only a weak reference to the observer. If the application has no references to the observer, it can be garbage collected.

Parameters:
observer - An implementation of XhiveDriverIf.XhiveDriverObserverIf.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0
